We make the transition easy by handling medical record transfers, and there's no judgment in finding the right match for your family. Your child's care is what matters most.

educational.title: When to Worry About Your Child's Fever
educational.hook: Is 102°F an emergency? Here's what pediatricians actually look for.
educational.body: Temperature numbers matter less than you think. We watch for these red flags: fever in babies under 3 months, lethargy despite fever reducers, difficulty breathing, or rash with fever. A playful kid with 103°F is often less concerning than a lethargic child with 100°F. Trust your parent instinct—you know your child best.
educational.cta: Save our after-hours nurse line: [PHONE]. We're here when you need guidance.

educational.title: The Real Vaccination Schedule Explained
educational.hook: Why so many shots in the first year? Let me break down the science.
educational.body: Babies get vaccines when they're most vulnerable to diseases. The schedule isn't arbitrary—it's based on immune system development and disease risk windows. We give multiple shots at once because it's actually easier on their immune system than spacing them out. Each vaccine has been tested for safety more rigorously than most medicines adults take daily.
educational.cta: Questions about vaccines? Our pediatricians spend time explaining, never rushing. Book a vaccine consultation.

educational.title: Ear Infection or Just Teething?
educational.hook: Your baby is pulling their ear and crying. Is it an infection?
educational.body: Ear tugging alone usually isn't an ear infection—babies discover their ears around 6 months. Look for these together: fever over 100.4°F, inconsolable crying especially when lying down, drainage from the ear, or cold symptoms that suddenly worsen. Teething causes drooling and chewing, but not high fever or ear drainage.
